new_research_designs.design_text: Case study of crowdsourced map digitization using novice volunteers with mobile GIS during archaeological fieldwork
new_research_designs.verbatim_quote: This article presents a case study of crowdsourced cultural heritage digitisation from historical maps undertaken by volunteers using a lightweight, streamlined Geographical Information System (GIS) running offline on mobile devices. The value of this approach lies in the unanticipated success of a minimally resourced digitisation effort, as well as the resulting dataset's value for archaeological research and cultural heritage management. Digitisation was undertaken as a secondary activity on a landscape archaeology project focusing on pedestrian feature survey. Undergraduates in the associated field school digitised data from maps using a system repurposed from other project activities.

scope_definition.data_scope: 10,827 burial/settlement mound features from 58 Soviet 1:50,000 topographic map tiles

indicators: Post-hoc comparative analysis with desktop GIS and ML

new_research_designs.design_text: Under what conditions do different map digitization approaches (expert GIS, volunteer GIS, crowdsourcing with mobile, ML) become worthwhile?
trigger_text: Existing research provides little guidance as to when investments in these approaches become worthwhile.
choosing between these approaches depends largely on the size of the dataset being digitised, we suggest payoff thresholds for each alongside qualitative assessments
new_research_designs.inference_reasoning: The paper repeatedly states that guidance is lacking on when different approaches are worthwhile, then provides threshold estimates. This implies an underlying research question about optimal approach selection, though not explicitly stated as a research question in Methods.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Research question not explicitly formulated in Methods section
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Difficult to assess if analysis directly addresses stated research aims vs post-hoc interpretation

new_research_designs.timing_basis: Abstract states study was designed to evaluate approach, and section 2.5 describes decision to 'catalogue inputs versus outputs' made early in 2017 season

new_methods.method_text: Crowdsourcing approach using mobile GIS platform (FAIMS Mobile) customized for map digitization by novice volunteers
new_methods.verbatim_quote: For the 2017–2018 field seasons, TRAP staff created a simplified and streamlined data capture system built using the FAIMS Mobile platform. This system allowed any number of participants to digitise map features using mobile devices, regardless of network connectivity, and consolidated the resulting data when a network became available.
new_methods.data_collection_approach: Volunteer digitization of georeferenced historical maps using customized mobile application
expected_information_missing: Volunteer recruitment criteria beyond 'field school participants'
Quality control procedures during digitization (documented after the fact in section 2.5)

new_methods.method_text: Platform selection: FAIMS Mobile chosen over desktop GIS and competing mobile platforms based on offline capability, functional requirements, usability transferability, platform reuse, student interface preferences, hardware/licensing constraints, and open-source transparency
new_methods.verbatim_quote: The decision to use mobile software, and FAIMS Mobile in particular, was based on several factors. First, FAIMS Mobile worked offline. Our digitisation took place alongside fieldwork, at field bases in rural Bulgaria. Reliable internet connectivity could not be guaranteed under these circumstances; a system that tolerated degraded network connectivity was required. In our experience, digitisation work associated with archaeological research often proceeds under such conditions. Second, this system met the functional requirements we identified for geospatial software.
new_methods.alternative_methods_considered: Desktop GIS (ArcGIS), ESRI ArcGIS Collector, ESRI Survey123
new_methods.selection_rationale: Offline operation, functional requirements met, usability approach transferability from fieldwork, platform reuse, student touch-screen preference, reduced hardware/licensing competition, open-source transparency

new_methods.method_text: Participant recruitment: Undergraduate field school students from range of Arts/Humanities backgrounds, most with no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods
new_methods.verbatim_quote: Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities. Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods (unlike Pődör, 2015 or Can et al., 2021).

sampling_strategy.sampling_rationale: Field school participants already present for archaeological survey
sampling_strategy.planned_coverage: All willing field school participants across 2017-2018 seasons

expected_information_missing: Total number of students in field school each year
Participation rate (how many students participated vs total enrolled)

new_methods.method_text: Comparative evaluation approach: cataloguing inputs (staff/volunteer time) versus outputs (features digitized) to evaluate approach efficiency
new_methods.verbatim_quote: At that point, we decided to catalogue inputs (time invested by staff and volunteers) versus outputs (features digitised) as part of a research program to evaluate digital approaches to fieldwork (e.g., Sobotkova et al., 2016). To measure inputs, we collated the amount of time spent by various participants in the process, including the student programmer who instantiated the customisation, the student volunteers who undertook the digitisation, and project staff who configured the system, supported volunteers, exported data, and checked for errors.
new_methods.analysis_approach: Time-motion study comparing person-hours invested to features produced; comparative threshold analysis against desktop GIS and ML approaches
expected_information_missing: Statistical analysis methods for comparing approaches

new_protocols.protocol_text: FAIMS Mobile customization for map digitization with simplified interface focused on layer selection, shape digitization, and annotation
new_protocols.verbatim_quote: Our approach sought to help novice users begin digitising quickly and then work productively for the duration of each field season with minimal support or frustration. As such, it stripped GIS functionality to its essentials, focusing on three tasks: layer selection, shape digitisation, and annotation, with validation and automation to improve data quality.
new_protocols.procedure_description: Customization strips full GIS to essential functions (layer selection, shape creation, attribute entry) with streamlined UI, automated metadata, validation, and offline sync

new_protocols.protocol_text: System customization workflow: (1) staff data/workflow modeling, (2) programmer customization (35h 2017, 1h 2018), (3) staff spatial reference and map preprocessing, (4) volunteer shape digitization, (5) volunteer attribute transcription, (6) staff data export, (7) staff accuracy checking
new_protocols.verbatim_quote: The stages of FAIMS Mobile implementation (Fig. 3) included: (1) project staff modelled the data and workflow to ensure that the final dataset met research needs, (2) a junior software developer worked with project staff to customise the system, (3) project staff defined a spatial reference system (SRS) and imported preprocessed historical maps, (4) volunteers drew a shape (usually a point) wherever they saw a target symbol and (5) volunteers transcribed attributes from the map, (6) project staff exported data using the FAIMS Mobile server, (7) project staff undertook a targeted accuracy-checking exercise.
procedure_steps: Programmer customize FAIMS Mobile (35h first season, 1h second season)
Staff define SRS and import preprocessed maps
Volunteers digitize point geometries at symbol locations
Staff export data from FAIMS server

new_protocols.protocol_text: Map preparation: tiling, adding pyramids to georeferenced GeoTIFFs of Soviet 1:50,000 topographic maps
new_protocols.verbatim_quote: Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h.
new_protocols.procedure_description: Preprocessing of georeferenced map tiles to optimize for mobile display and navigation
tools_used: GIS software for tiling and pyramid generation (specific tool not specified)
